page.title: 15BRITISH WATERWAYS,STANLEY.
page.content: THE WATERWAYS COMPLEX AT STANLEY FERRY CONSISTS OF TWO AQUEDUCTS TRANSPORTING THE AIRE AND CALDER NAVIGATION CANAL OVER THE RIVER CALDER, A BARGE HARBOUR, A DRY DOCK, WORKSHOPS AND REPAIR YARD. THE CAST IRON AQUEDUCT BUILT IN 1837, THE ONLY ONE OF ITS TYPE REMAINING, IS A LISTED BUILDING. IT WAS REPLACED IN 1982 BY ONE MADE OF CONCRETE.THE BARGE HARBOUR CONTAINS THE REMAINS OF STAITHES BY WHICH COAL WAS LOADED INTO SMALL BARGES CALLED TOM PUDDINGS UNTIL 1950. IN THE REPAIR YARD FITTERS MAINTAIN MACHINERY AND VEHICLES, WHILE VESSELS ARE OVERAULED IN THE DRY DOCK. LOCK GATES ARE MADE IN THE WORKSHOPS FROM OAK PINE AND ELM, THE CRAFTSMEN USING VARIOUS MACHINES INCLUDING A BANDSAW, CIRCULAR SAWS AND MORTICE-AND-TENNON. THERE IS AN OVERHEAD GANTRY CRANE FOR LIFTING HUGE BAULKS OF TIMBER.
